Introduction Fn the last ten years, there has been intense interest in intercalation compounds of graphite, not only from a view-point of fundamental chemistry [1, 2] and physics [3, 41 but also toward the development of materials useful as catalysts [5, 61 , reagents [i, 81, electronic conductors [9, IQj, battery components [11, 121 , and lubricating agents [131 . The rapid pace of the research in the various disciplines has not, however, allowed a thorough integration of all knowledge gained. In reviewing catalysis by graphite compounds, we will, also critically analyze recent developments in compound characterization and chemistry. This will give the reader both the facts of what has been done and some insight into what could be done in the area of catalysis. Background As seen in Fig. 1, graphite possesses a layered structure, consisting of planes of sp2 - hybridized benzenoid carbon. Interactions between sheets are through van der Waals forces, the weakness of which is perceived in the excellent lubricity of graphite. The intercalation of graphite is a redog process, in which ions and sometimes neutral species enter the interlamellar voids without disrupting the layered topology of graphite. In a chemical sense, the intercalation of graphite is analogous to the formation of ions of aromatic molecules [141 , as schematically depicted in Fig. 2. Graphite will react either with chemical reductants (such as potassium metal) or chemical oxidants (such as arsenic pentafluoridej to force respectively an `infinite' aromatic anion or- cation: 8C + R - C-S r~Ki_r (~ SC 1 ASli 5 GSr(ASjr(Si2 - L5r(F3ld.S. Orthogonal to the planes, one frequently observes specific sequences of filled and unfilled interlamellar voids. Ns shown inE Fig. 3, the concept of `staging' is used to describe this order along the c axis, although, to some extent, such a concept is an idealization [15, 161 . Along the graphite plane, one may observe an epitaxial relationship of intercalated species to the benzenoid array, as exemplified by the frequently encountered CBX network of Fig. ?_ Because intercalation compounds possess translationally periodic structures, band analysis, rather than a simple chemical bonding approach, is required to fully appreciate the physical characteristics arising from the changes in electron density of the benzenoid planes- What kind of chemistry do we expect from intercalation compounds? The chemical and catalytic properties that we anticipate from intercalation compounds depend critically on the extent of charge transfer, as embodied by the paxameter x in eqns. (Z) and (2)_ High values of charge transfer would lead us to expect the chemistry of infinite aromatic ions (and corresponding guest counter-ions), rather than the chemistry of the initial neutral reacting species. Lower values of x would allow for the simultaneous presence of the chemistry of aromatic ions, guest counter-ions, and of the initial neutral reagent. We believe that concentrated intercalation compounds of graphite (i.e. C8X - C12X) are most adequately described by the latter situation, in which at least some of the initial reagent intercalates into graphite without undergoing redox chemistry with the graphite matrix. This obvious property, color, yields significant insight into the charge transfer mechanism when analyzed in terms of the appropriate dielectric theories. Specifically, in 1965, fiennig [I9) recognized that the optical reflectance of intercalated graphite is dominated by the free electrons on the benzenoid planes arising from t-he charge transfer aspect of intercalation- Thus, a C&M compound is a plasma, in which the excess, delocalized 278 electrons on the graphite planes are balanced 5y an equal- number of metal ions. One can infer the extent of this charge transfer by performing optical spectroscopy. When the intercalation compounds of graphite with SbFs [29] and with AsFs [30] were first reported, they were proposed as reagents which pos sessed the chemistry of the initial, neutral species (i.e. SbF5 or AsF5). Addi tionally, reports suggesting these compounds as catalysts in paraffin isomeri zation .,were predicated on the existence of neutral metal fluoride in the graphite [31] . Nevertheless, there was evidence for some redox chemistry, with the initial paper on CIOAsF5 (a polycrystalline material containing stages 1 and 2) noting the recovery of about 5% AsF3 (on an arsenic basis) following vacuum treatment of the sample [30] - Later, more sophisticated studies employing a mass spectrometer showed this vacuum dried C1oAsF5 to liberate only AsF5 between 25 and 200 C [32]. Early NMR work gave insight into both the chemical identity and mobility of inserted species. Wide line i9F NMR of both graphite/SbFs [33, 34] and graphite/AsF5 [1, 35] showed a single, r-arrow resonance in each compound at room temperature, indicating a correlation time of motion for fluorine of faster than 10-5 sec onds. The chemical shifts of these resonances were measured at 35 MHz against external CFXOOH, and the values of 18 ppm downfield for graphite/ AsF5 and 42 ppm up' field for graphite/SbF5 were stated to be consistent with either MF5 or MFG-, but not vAth MF3, although the presence of fluorine exchange could allow the presence of minor amounts of trivalent material. 281 In 1978, Bartlett utilized data from the X-ray absorption edge of arsenic in the graphite compounds GgAsFs and C1oAsF5 to infer a degree of charge transfer higher than that previously reported [36, 37l ] . Specifically, the Xray spectrum of C1oAsF5 revealed two peaks of height ratio two to one, which were identified as As(V) and As(III) resulting from the reaction: lOC f AsF5 Cl0'67(ASF6)0.67(AsF3)0.33 (12) In the case of C$AsF6, made from the action of 2 AsF6 on graphite, only As(V) is observed in the X-ray spectrum of the product: SC i- OzAsF6 -> CaAsFs i- 02 (13) Both of these compounds were blue in reflectance. The new way of looking at graphite/ AsFs embodied in eqn. (12) was different from previous thought in two key ways: first, it predicted graphite/ AsF5 to possess no neutral AsF5; and second, it predicted a charge transfer at least twice as high as previously thought, and, in so doing, implicitly suggested the optical approach of eqn. The latter has been utilized not only by workers in graphite [38] but also by workers in the field of polyacetylene [39] . Nevertheless, eqn. (12) does not explain the observed optical properties (a compound so highly oxidized should not be blue in reflectance [40] ), the observed nuclear magnetic resonance properties (a compound containing only AsF6 and AsF3 should reveal discrete 19F resonances for AsF6 and AsF3 [41 - 43] ) or electron spin resonance properties (the radical density measured by either Schumacher-Schlicter [44] or by double integration [43] is much lower than predicted by eqn. (Z2)). One possible explanation for the discrepancy may lie in the potentially different X-ray absorption oscillator strengths of AsF3 and AsFs/AsF6 species. Such an effect has been documented for tetrahedral and octahedral Fe(II) species, in which the absorption of the tetrahedral species is ten times more intense than that of an equivalent amount of the octahedral species [45] . f course, from the point of view of catalysis by graphite compounds, the key issue is the actual chemistry of the compounds, rather than our physical perception of what that chemistry should be. The first paper on graphite/ CbF5 noted that even dilute (e.g. 5 wt.%) compounds would hydrolyze in moist air, every though the rate of hydrolysis was slower for intercalates than for free SbFs [29] . Later, work on the conductivity of graphite/SbFS discussed problems with both corrosion and hydrolysis, and even provided explicit IR and XPS evidence for the fluorination of graphite by SbFs [46] . A study on the thermal and hydrolytic stability of both graphite/SbF5 and graphite/AsFs found these compounds prone not only to hydrolysis hut also to thermal devolatilisation [47] . The above behavior should in principle arise from the neutral species MF3 or MFs rather than the stable and sonically bound MF6 species (in fact, AsF6 is used as a probe of dynamics in aqueous biological systems, in a manner similar to that of spin labels [48] ). In light of all of the above evidence, the reader should note that concentrated compounds of graphite with either SbFs or Asps act as if they have neutral MFs species within them. This neutral molecular character of graphite/halides accepted, one notes that there are alternative chemical models to explain the observed chemistry. Such discussion has centered about the reversibility of eqn. (12). Bartlett, to account for the presence of molecular character, has suggested eqn. (12) to be readily reversible, not only for graphite/Asps compounds [50] but also for graphite/GeF4/F2 compounds [51] . Moran et al. have stated that eqn. (12) is not reversible because AsF3 is not capable of reducing CgAsF5 [52] . Although the above differences have not been reconciled, we believe that there is an additional eauilibrium involved, one which is of potential interpretive significance in catalytic and chemical areas [43] C-MF6 +MFS --, C-(M2Fii) (16) Thus, while we accept the stoichiometry of eqn. (12) for the oxidative intercalation of graphite, we believe that there is a fundamental limit beyond which graphite cannot be reversibly oxidized, and at this limit neutral molecules will intercalate in the manner of eqn. (16). Such a limit was proposed as C'X- by Rudorff and Hofmann hi 1938 [53], was placed at C+X- in the early reviews [ 54, 55] , and confirmed at CZ4X- by later coulometric studies [27, 28] . In summary, we believe that equilibria of the type given in eqn. X16) give rise to many of the chemical and catalytic properties of graphite compounds, with the graphite macro-cation stabilizing the formation of complex anions, which in themselves are the source of the observed neutral molecular behavior. 284 An overview of catalysis by graphi~e compounds Intercalation compounds of graphite have been stated to be effective catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch chemistry, Friedel-Crafts chemistry, aromatic hydrogenation, ammonia synthesis, polymerization initiation, steam gzsifica.tion of carbon, and reforming chemistry [1, 2, 8] . Much of the early work has been discussed in specialized reviews [61 - 63] . Our objectives in the following are to determine the chemically active form of the graphite species and to assess whether cr not it is acting catalytically. Fischer- Tropsch chemistry The first report of the use of graphite compounds in Fischer-'lropsch chemistry was by Ichikawa and coworkers in 1969 [64] . For a graphite/ sodium `compound' (4.6 mol carbon/1 mol sodium), they found a 3090 conversion of CO into hydrocarbons (carbon atom basis), of which ethane (74% of total hydrocarbons) and propane (22%) were the most abundant. A closed reaction system was employed at typical Fischer-'lropsch conditions (300 C, H2/CO = 4, p(HZ) = 400 mmHg). Since the molar ratio of sodium to carbon monoxide yeas over 100, no assessment of catalytic behavior could be made, and, in fact, excess sodium metal was present (the most concentrated known graphite/Na compound is C64Na [1] ). Rosynek and Winder have greatly clarified the chemistry of graphite/ alkali metals with CO/HZ mixtures [65, 66] _ Edith C6,Na as a catalyst (300 C, HZ/CO = 4, total initial pressure = 700 mmHg, stirred batch system of the closed-loop recirculation type), C2 hydrocarbons (ethane + ethylene) were the most abundant hydrocarbon products (60 - 650) over a range of CO conversions (Q - 1590). Additionally 25 to 30'0 of the hydrocarbons were C3. Significantly, no CO? was found in the products, even though its presence is expected through reactions (19) and (20): CO + H2 -> (CH2) y H20 (19) 2 H20 T CO water-gas shit H2 CO? ( 0) The absence of C02 is directly linked to the instability of graphitelalkalimetals to water (refer to eqns. (4) - (6)), for no CO? can be formed through eqn. (20) if water itself is reacting irreversibly with the materials. Of course, C02, if formed, would also react with CgK. Such a thesis suggests that graphiste/all-ali metals will be readily deactivated once stoichiometric (eon. (4)) amounts of water have been formed via eqn- (19). For the case of CsK, Rosynek and Winder demonstrated that this product `inhibition' does occur, with repeated reaction cycling yielding an integrated turnover of one CO converted for every three potassium species in the catalyst [66] . One could view this substoichdometry either in terms of the fractional ionization of alkali metal (i.e., only the electrons on the potas- sium layers are a%railable for chemistry) or in terms of kinetic inhibition by the product KOH (i.e., more chemistry could occur if the active `sites' were 285 not blocked [66] ). In any event, graphite/alkali metals do not function as catalysts under conditions so far employed. Other intercalation systems have been suggested for use in Fischer- Tropsch chemistry. Most of these involve chemically reduced compounds formed as in eqn. (21.): C (MX .) ~ rrrR - 'C Mo' + mRX (21) in which M = transition metal, such as Fe, Co, Re, Ru, Os, Mn, Cu, Pt, Pd X - halogen R = reducing agent, such as alkali metal or hydrogen In the case of reduction by alkali metals, one has the advantage of possessing a metallic catalyst which may be promoted, as known for various Fe/K sys tems [6 7) . In terms of identifying the actual catalyst, however, there is the added complication that the free, unintercalated, metal is itself a catalyst, so that the mere presence of hydrocarbon products in these systems does not, by itself, prove the catalytic ability of intercalation compounds. The first examples of chemically reduced graphite/metal halides as Fischer-Tropsch catalysts came in 19 72 from the group of Tamaru [68, 69] . They took the product of heating ten to one by weight mixtures of graphite and either FeC13 or OsC13 11'corresponding to CissFeC13 or C247OSCIg), and reduced vrzth excess potassium (K/MC13 > 40), yielding what must be considered primarily CgK-type compounds, since they were reported as gold rather than blue in color (see eqn. (3)). When these materials were placed in a mixture of N2, CO and H2 (100:100:300 mmHg) at 300 C, `a large arnount of hydrocarbons were obtained' [68).rtherwork v-ith a graphite/PdCl2/Na mixture prepared in an analogous manner led to the formation of dimethyl ether from H2 (300 mmHg) and C02 (300 mmHg) at 250 C [69] . Novikov and Vol'pin confirmed the Fischer-Tropsch activity of these hybrid materials, although their initial metal chloride contents were much higher than those of the Ichikawa group [ 701 . As an example of their mate rials preparation, we have Ca.3FeC13 + K ioo c, Ar ~ `Ca.aFeCl3K5.e' (22) (3.1 g, 12 mmol) (2.7 g, 63 mmol) A flow-through system was used for the Fischer-'Iropsch chemistry, with CO/H2 mixtures (ca. 1:1) introduced onto H2-pretreated catalysts (300 C, 30 min) at a flow rate of 0.6 1/hour. In the case of a cobalt catalyst prepared as in eqn. (21), the yield of methane (based on CO passed) gbes from 1.9. 0 to 2390 as the K/Co ratio goes from 1 to 7. While methane is the predominant product for these reactions (93 to 300`7o of total hydrocarbons), ethane is the predominant product for pure CsK (1.4% conversion, 64.390 of which is ethane). This divergence between CgK and graphite/transition metal/K com pounds was found for Co, Ru, Fe, Os, 14 In, and Ni, but: was not found far Or, Cu, Pt, and. Pd (which yielded primarily ethane, as with C&K itself). There was no proof of catalysis, for the level of metals involved (11..9 mmol transi- 286 tion metal, 23.8 - 35.7 mmol K) was larger than that of CO converted (less than 3 mmol). The shift in product selectivity between C&K and certain hybrid compounds, which suggests that the transition metal participates in the reaction, was confirmed by Rosynek and Winder [66] . Using a hybrid graphite/FeC13/K compound (final Fe level 4.5 0), these workers noted methane to be the primary hydrocarbon product (60 to 80% of converted CO) over a conversion range of 0 to B0. o (300 C, HZ/CO = 4, initial pressure 700 mmHg). Ps with CBK anti C64Na materials, no C02 was observed, presumably because of the reaction of water with the graphite compound. Furthermore, the behavior of the iron-containing potassium graphite was also distinct from that of a conventional iron catalyst (14.9 wt_% Fe on alumina reduced in hydrogen), which showed not only C02 but also olefins in the product slate. For conversions greater than 1090, this conventional catalyst led to as much as 2590 C3 hydrocarbons. If, however, the conventional catalyst was prepared by reduction with potassium, rather than with hydrogen, the sole carboncontaining product was again methane, as with the hybrid graphite/iron/ potassium catalyst, a result which suggests that the chemistry of the ironpotassiem system itself, rather than that of the graphite/iron `intercalate', dictates the observed product slate [66] . Kikuchi and coworkers have prepared graphite/iron species by reduction with hydrogen, rather than with alkali metal [71 - 73] . The results of this study are not directly comparable to the preceding, for reaction temperature (300 - 500 C) and reaction pressure (1 - 20 atm) were much more extreme than those of previous workers. As with the hybrid graphite/iron/ potassium catalyst, methane was the predominant hydrocarbon product. There was no C02 observed at 190 or 6% conversions (at 300 and 350 C), although it was observed at higher conversions. In closing this section on Fischer-Tropsch chemistry, we note that much work remains to be done, not only from a scientific but also from a technical point of view. Of the former, the identity of the active species remains undetermined, with controversies still raging over the nature of various hybrid graphite compounds [74, 75] . Specifically, while the Kikuchi group considered intercalated iron metal to be responsible for the Fischer'!ropsch activity in their system, Parkash et a!. have presented strong evidence favoring iron outside of the graphite to be responsible [76, 77] . Technical assessment of these `catalysts' is difficult in the absence of proof demonstrating catalytic, rather than stoichiometric, chemistry. Furthermore, detailed data on activity, in terms of a space velocity (as volume gas converted/(volume catalysts X tine)) is frequently missing. Synthesis of ammonia Many of the materials used for Fischer-Tropsch chemistry have also been used to effect ammonia synthesis. In 1969, the group of Tamaru suggested that ammonia could be formed catalytically from a 1_1 mixture of hydrogen and nitrogen (total pressure ca. 15 crn) in the temperature range 287 50 - 400 C by means of unspecified complexes of graphite with sodium or potassium [78] . Conversions could be enhanced by formation of ternary systems, with a graphite/FeCl3/K system (2:0.2:2 on a weight basis) yielding a 909o conversion of N2 into NH3 in 10 h at 350 C [68] . As with the Fischer` Tropsch chemistry, the assessment of catalytic behavior was impossible because of the high ratio of metals to nitrogen reacted (1.2 mmol Fe/51.1 mmol K/1.6 mmol NZ). T'ne group of Novikov and Vol'pin have also studied ammonia synthesis promoted through chemically reduced graphite/metal chloride compounds [79]. in addition to the graphite/FeC13 /K system 12.7 mmol Fe/gram; K/Fe = 5 to 20), similar materials were obtained with FeCla replaced by either RuC13 or OsC13 and with potassium replaced by lithium biphenyl. The optimum K/Fe ratio for ammonia synthesis was 5 - 7, indicating That the active species was more than simply reduced iron (K/Fe = 3), most likely involving the reduction of the graphite by potassium and K/Fe alloy formation. The most active catalysts were the graphite/RuC13/K and graphite/OSC13/FeCl3/K systems. Curiously, hydrolysis of spent catalysts yielded not only ammonia but also cyanide ion. In a later paper [80] , the catalyst of empirical formula Cg_s(OSC13)Kli was found to be most active, converting 1.5% of the nitrogen into ammonia. at 200 C and 100% at 350 C (72 h). While it is clear that these hybrid materials can be used in both ammonia and FischerTropsch chemistry [81 - 83] , their identity as intercalation compounds of transition metal atoms has been questioned [35, 83] . There is no definitive X-ray diffraction data on the hybrid compounds, and, in fact, the large excess of alkali metal employed suggests that CSK itself could be formed. Except in these cases involving reduction of a pre-formed metal halide intercalation compound, there is no evidence for a direct insertion of transition metal atoms into graphite [1, 2] . Nevertheless, in terms of the ultimate technical use of these compounds, one must look beyond the intercalate/non-intercalate issue to determine whether or not their chemistry can be catalytic. Even if the materials are found to be finely dispersed, but nonintercalated, metal, they could be useful catalysts [84, 85] , and intercalation compounds could be novel precursors to catalysts which are not themselves intercalation compounds. Friedel-C.-ajs hemistry Va-.-ious graphite/halide compounds have been suggested for use as cata15 its ir, the alkylation of aromatics by olefins or alkyl halides. Such alkyl aromatic products are of use as chemical intermediates, such as ethyl benzene in tae production of styrene. Lalancette et al. [86] compared the behavior of the intercalation compound C26AIC13_1 with that of pure AIC13 and found the intercalate to be a milder catalyst, giving fewer polysubstituted products As an example, in the reaction of benzene with ethylene (75 C, 24 h), the intercalate yielded 4790 diethyl benzene, 22 'o triethyl benzene, and 19 0 monoethyl benzene, while pure AIC13 yielded 53% tetraethyl benzene, 25 0 triethyl benzene, and 18% pentaethyl benzene. 288 To clarify the identity of the catalyst, Olah and coworkers used intercalation compounds of graphite with AIC13, AlBr3, SbFs, and FeCl3 to promote the gas phase ethylation of benzene by ethylene [871. In a flow system with a fixed bed catalyst (125 - 200 'C. benzene/ethylene = 3.2 - 3.6, 1 g catalyst, flow = 0.02 ml/min), the iron compound was inactive, the antimony compound deactivated after I h, and the AIC13 and AlBr3 compounds lasted unly 6 - 8 h. Studies of the reacted AlC13 catalyst showed bath leaching of inserted material from the intercalate and hydrolysis by trace moisture of the AIC13 within the intercalate. Furthermore, the possibility of deactivation through surface ethylene polymerization was mentioned. Since AIC13 is leaving the graphite, it is not clear whether the catalyst is AIC13 ire graphite or AIC13 on graphite. Work by Olah on paraffin alkylation chemistry catalyzed by pure NbFs, NbFs in graphite (C61NbFs), and NbFs on graphite (29 wt.% NbFS) shows how subtle this distinction can be [88] . Reacting 2-chloropropane with 2-methyl butane over each of the above, Olah found quick deactivation with the intercalate, a slow deactivation with pure NbFs (through build-up of polymerization products), and the NbF5 on graphite gave the best yields and the highest conversions. Thus, one may infer that a difference in chemistry between a free phase and an intercalated phase need not prove the presence of intercalation-modified chemistry, for the reagent may be modified by being on graphite. In the area of alkylation of alkylaromatics, both CgK and CgCs have been claimed to be effective catalysts [89] . Specifically, propylene adds to toluene to form iso-butylbenzene unaccompanied by the formation of 2methylindan. Paraffin isomerization chemistry The isomerization of straight-chain paraffins to branched paraffins by means of acid catalysts has been of interest in forming high octane gasoline [90, 91] . A logical extension of the use of free acid catalysts has been the use of intercalated acid catalysts, whose modified activity might suppress the formation of dele-,~-_rious high molecular weight products. Inspection of the recent patent literature reveals numerous claims for intercalated graphite materials as catalysts for chemistry involving carbonium ions [92 - 104] . The key issues here are exactly those found in Friedel-Crafts chemistry: is the intercalation compound itself a catalyst or does it act by `bleeding off' active acid catalyst, ultimately yielding a deactivated species? In the case of isomerization of cyclohexane to methylcyclopentane, Rodewald [31] claimed that intercalated SbFs (Ci2SbFs) was more active than an SbFs/graphite mixture (60 wt.% SbFs). Unfortunately, there was no proof that the Sb Fs/graphite mixture, made in 902 at -30 C, was not in fact an intercalate. Recent wo=k has shown that SbFs can directly intercalate graphite even at room temperature [46] , and solvents such as CCI.& or S02C1z are known to promote intercalation in systems which would otherwise not intercalate [1, 2] . Furthermore, SOz is known to form complexes both with 289 SbFS [105] and with AsFs [106], and such complexes, in graphite, would stabilize the intercalation compound through screening of interanionic repulsions (some SbF6 will be present in any intercalation compound). Thus, the graphite/SbFs mixture is likely to be an intercalation compound itself, which is more chemically passive than the CE2SbF5 because of SbFs/S02 interactions. Generally, in isomerizations, graphite/SbF5 does seem to promote the formation of the thermodynamically most stable hydrocarbon isomer. For the cyclohexane/methylcyclopentane conversion, one notes that methylcyclopentane is less stable than cyclohexane at room temperature (AG = -0.96 kcal/mol for the formation of cyclohexane, indicating KeQ = 5), and if one starts with methylcyclopentane, one obtains primarily cyclohexane when using graphite/SbFs [107] . Similarly, thermodynamically-controlled results are obtained for cis/t-raps mixtures of both decalin and perhydroindan [107]. Unfortunately, there is evidence indicating rapid deactivation of graphite/ Lewis acid catalysts, which suggests that they might not be commercially attractive [87, 108 - 1101. Interest has shifted to mixtures of fluorinated graphite with Lew-is acids, compounds first reported by us [34, 111 - 113] . Olah [108, 109] has claimed such catalysts to be effective in the cracking and isomerization of n-alkanes, the alkylation of alkanes with olefins, Friedel-Crafts chemistry (specifically the formation of ethyl benzene from ethylene and benzene), transmethylation and isomerization of xylenes, paraffin alkylation, and the polymerization of alkenes. As a specific example, (C3.3F)s_sSbFs. i. a fluid bed reactor at 120 C, converted 4090 of continuously-passed heptane into cracked and isomerized products, the most abundant of which were methylpropane (14.1%) and propane (7.490). Nevertheless, in a study of the hydroisomerization of pentane to isopentane over CF/SbFs (23 C, 2 g pentane/(g, cat-hour), H2/CS molecular ratio 125, p(H2) = 2 - 30 bar), Heinerman and Gaaf reported measurable deactivation to occur within 10 h, which they attributed to poisoning of active sites by unsaturated heavy products [110] . The chemical characteristics of CF/SbFs were found.to be the same as those of homogeneous HF/ SbFs with respect to disproportionation reactions (i.e. isobutane formation), influence of hydrogen pressure, and deactivation mechanism (i.e. unsaturated heavy products are the origin of activity decline in both HF/SbFs and CF/SbFs )- There is some disagreement about the nature of CF./MFG, catalysts. Our motivation for trying the reaction- of CF., with SbF5 [34, 112] was to determine if a good fluoride acceptor (SbFs) could react with the tertiary carbonfluorine bonds of CF_ to make carbonium ions, a reaction which is known in the literature [114, 11.5] . C-F f SbF5 i C+SbFs (23) This chemistry of fluoride ion removal is different from the redox chemistry of the fundamental intercalation reactions, as depicted in eqns. (1) and (2). 290 Since the scope of the reaction is local, involving the rupture of a C-F bong, it may occur both inside and on the surface of the CF microcrystallites. Once formed, SbF6 could react with SbFs to form Sb2F-11, or even larger complex ions, a-a discussed in eqn. (16), thereby gaining the chemistry of SbFs while maintaining an anchor to the substrate through the C+SbF6 interaction. To the extent that SbF3 might be present, complexes of SbFs with SbF3 might also occur [116] . In terms of chemical results, we reported SbFs to react more fully with CFl_06 than with CFl_ls [112] . Our formulae were based on carbon combustion analysis, vrith the actual compounds listed by Ozark-Mahoning as CFl_o and CF,._,. Neither X-ray diffraction nor electron spin resonance reveals the presence of a free graphite phase in these materials. Combustion analysis of the SbFS containing product indicated an empirical formula of CFl_06Ho.37(SbF5)0.o9, with the presence of hydrogen in the product immediately suggesting possible HF/SbFs-like chemistry [112] . This product displayed ionic (rather than electronic) conductivity and possessed thermal stability intermediate between that of pure CF and graphite/SbFs [34] . In contrast, Heinerman and Gaaf [1101 have suggested that there is no reaction of SbFs iv_th CF=, with apparent chemistry arising from the reaction of SbF5 with graphite phases existing within CF=. While we agree with their conclusion in the case of CFo_e (which X-ray diffraction shows to be biphasic), our results suggest that `C4F' (actual empirical formula C3_2zFHo_2t [112]) and CFl_06 bath react with SbFs even though neither material shows the presence of graphite in X-ray diffraction. Although there is disagreement about the detailed structure of CF/SbFs, all workers in the field of graphite catalysts agree that it is the chemistry of the neutral Lewis acid, along with possible trace quantities of protons, which create the observed chemistry- The goal of this chemistry is to cause rearrangement of carbonium ions, formed as in eqns. (24) and (25), to the most stable form without performing the polymerization chemistry arising through eqns. (26) and (27): RH + SbFs dry R+ + `SbFSH-' (24) RH + HF wet R+ + H2 + F- (25) R+ - 1 olefin + fl+ (26) R+ + R lefin ~ R2 (27) Experiments so far reported have not demonstrated that compounds of graphite (or CF=) with Lewis acids offer unusual protection against deactivation through laydown of carbonaceous materials, although it is reasonable that, with the appropriate system, such protection could be afforded. In any event, interest in this field is expanding [1171 . 291 Catalysis of reactions involving molecular hydrogen Graphitefalkali metal compounds interact directly with molecular hydrogen to varying degrees, ranging from the chemical reaction of CSK at room temperature to form a blue, second-stage CgKH213 [118] to the physical interaction of C24M (M = K, Rb, Cs) to form-compounds such as C24MH [61] . Such compounds are likely to be involved in the various hydrogen exchange reactions promoted by graphite/alkali metal compounds [6] : orthopara hydrogen conversion, hydrogen-deuterium exchange, and propylenedeuterium exchange- Of the last, microwave spectroscopic measurements of the gaseous products of C2,tK with propylene and deuterium at 120 C showed the initially most prevalent dideuterimn product to be CHD2-CH=.CH2 (5090) with approximately equal amounts of cis-CH2D--CH=CHD (2290) and traps-CH?D-CH=CHD (2590) [119] . This data, along with the observation of CH2DCH=CH2 as the dominant initial mono-deuterated product, led Kondo and co-workers to postulate a ,r-allyl intermediate (CHz-CH-CHz) in the exchange reaction [119] . This ability of graphite/alkali metal compounds to break carbonhydrogen bonds led Lalancette and Roussel [120] to investigate a number of reactions, including the reduction of olefins and alkynes, the isomerization of cis-stilbene to traps-stilbene, the isomerization of 2-alkynes to 1alkynes, and the condensation of benzene to biphenyl. While there is little doubt of the nature of the performed chemistry, the presence of catalysis is not confirmed, as we may see in the benzene condensation: C 4- K - C2K (28) (5 g, 4-2 mmol) (0.8 g, 21 mmol) (listed as `C2AK') C?K t C6 H6 i Ci-Hio (29) (21 mmol) (26 mmol) (2.6 mmol) The amount of alkali metal present is four times greater than the amount of benzene reacted (21 mmol/5.2 mmol). Similarly, in the isomerization of cisstilbene to traps-stilbene, the amount of alkali metal used is seven times greater (19 mmol/2.8 mmol). In fact, in a study of the isomerization of 1pentene to cis- and franc-2-pentene, Ottmers and Rase [121] found conversion to drop from 68 to 35% within one hour, indicative of rapid `catalyst' deactivation. As in Fischer-Tropsch and ammonia chemistry, hybrid compounds involving transition metal and alkali metal have been proposed as catalysts in hydrogenation reactions [122] . Specifically, the product of reaction of PdClz with CgK in 1,2-dimethoxyethane has been stated to be a catalyst for the quantitative hydrogenation of oct-2-ene, 3-methylnitrobenzene, and 4-nitrobenzoic acid to octane, 3-methylamirobenzene, and 4-aminobenzoic acid respectively. With a!kynes, atmospheric hydrogenation at room temperature led predominantly to the alkene (without stereospecificity) and minor amounts of alkane. 292 Catalysis of anionic polymerizations Anionic polymerizations of ethylene, styrene, isoprene, and various dienes are initiated by graphite/alkali metal compounds, with chain growth proposed to occuz within the graphite planes [123] . Recent attention has centered on the anionic polymerization of lactones [124] . While there is little doubt of the performed chemistry, one notes that the intercalation compounds are decomposed in this type of chemistry [124-] and thus are not catalysts. Catalysis of steam gasification of carbon Intercalation compound-like structures have been proposed as the active intermediates not. only in the steam gasification of carbon [125] but also in similar chemistries [126] . ' he validity of these proposals is unclear, simply because the coals and cmorphous carbons so far studied have a high ratio of peripheral carbon to internal carbon relative to graphite, rendering their chemistry more similar to molecular aromatic hydrocarbons than to graphite [24, 127] . Furthermore, substituents on the aromatic structures of such species will also modify their chemistry. Specifically, Mims and Pabst [128] have articulated a carbon gasification mechanism based on chemistry at the edges of aromatic species, which suggests that the chemistry of a, rather than ;r, electrons is the key feature of gasification. Conclusions Although intercalation compounds of graphite do perform interesting and somewhat unexpected chemistry, there is as yet no definitive evidence demonstrating their role as catalysts in commercially significant processes. In the case of transition metal/alkali metal hybrid compounds, intercalation compounds may serve as unique precursors to catalysts which are themselves not intercalation compounds [129] .
